title: Fatwa
summary: A fatwā (/ˈfætwɑː/, also US: /ˈfɑːtwɑː/; Arabic: فتوىٰ‎; plural fatāwā فتاوىٰ) is a nonbinding legal opinion on a point of Islamic law (sharia)  given by a qualified jurist in response to a question posed by a private individual, judge or government.[1][2][3] A jurist issuing fatwas is called a mufti, and the act of issuing fatwas is called iftāʾ.[1] Fatwas have played an important role throughout Islamic history, taking on new forms in the modern era.[4][5]
